title: 107_s930
content:
The "Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001" includes sections on short title, definitions, fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, park surcharge, use of bond proceeds, report, and regulations. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Fundraising organization - entity authorized under section 3(a).
Memorandum of agreement - agreement entered into by the Secretary under section 3(a) with terms specified in section 4.
Park - Grand Canyon National Park.
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary can make a deal with an entity to fundraise for the Park through taxable bonds. The fundraising organization must follow professional standards and laws, undergo audits, and the US is not liable for the bonds. The fundraising organization must comply with laws and undergo an audit by the Secretary. The US is not responsible for the security of any bonds issued by the organization. SEC. 4. MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, bond maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, project funding at the Park, and procedures for agreement modifications. The fundraising organization and the Secretary must agree on bond issue details, project funding, and agreement modifications based on changing circumstances. SEC. 5. PARK SURCHARGE OR SET-ASIDE. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts, which include the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act, the recreational fee demonstration program, and the national park passport program. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts, such as the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act, the recreational fee demonstration program, and the national park passport program. The total amount charged or set aside may not exceed $2 for each individual charged an entrance fee. The surcharge shall be used by the fundraising organization to amortize the bond issue, cover administration costs, and maintain a sufficient reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations and prohibitions on administrative use. The bond proceeds can be used for projects in the Park, following specific limitations and prohibitions on administrative expenses. Interest earned on the bond proceeds can be used for reserve requirements and reasonable administrative expenses related to managing and selling the bonds. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of regulations being issued, reviewing the bond program at the Park and providing recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park units. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
